ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Political ideologies in recent history
The similarities and differences between different thinkers that have shaped our modern society
How to write H&P papers more clearly and with more structure
I learned how to think critically about the sentiments of political theorists, and draw comparisons between others as well. I also learned how to write more structurally in history.
I learned about history and political thought from Machiavelli to Arendt, and I developed my writing skills.
A broad understanding of modern political thought as well as close reading and clear/persuasive writing skills.

I developed my academic writing, analytical reading, and discussion skills. Prof. Sorkin pushed us to really ground our papers in the text and read the text thoroughly. I really like that the thinkers this semester definitely helped shape modern politics, making the course feel more relevant and tangible than first semester H&P.
close reading/analysis, writing a detailed text-based analysis, sharing thoughts about the reading and interacting with peers in a discussion
you really learn to identify patterns and critically think about the themes in each work. Sorkin does a great job asking the right questions in discussion.

This course helped me develop a greater intensity in textual analysis than my other Directed Studies courses required. This was true in our written assignments, but Professor Sorkin also emphasized the use quotations and student engagement in the class discussion so that we always hewed very closely to the thinkers at hand.

I feel like this semester, I definitely learned much more than I did last semester what it means to write an H&P paper or even to really analyze political philosophy texts. I think in this class,
I pushed myself to participate a lot, and it was really helpful for my self-confidence. Not to mention, I was exposed to a lot of new content I hadnt read before.

I developed an ability closely analyze and discuss complex historical texts from Machiavelli to Arendt and their implications and influence in their historical context or modern age. I learned how to write clearer and more concisely over the course of our three papers and feedback.
This course helped me to develop my close reading and analytical thinking skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths of this course were its content and discussions.

Strengths:  format of small seminars with weekly lectures, great at teaching writing and analysis skills, stimulates fascinating discussions

I think the reading load was a bit steep this semester, and there was a lot we didn't get to.  I also would like to see a more diverse syllabus, including with some more contemporary readings (going past Arendt).

This class is fantastic as it is, but I would recommend that some lectures be made longer/offer more historical context and analysis of passages--there were some points during the semester when a more in-depth lecture would have deepened my understanding of our authors. I really enjoyed the brief student presentations at the beginning of each class and the fact that students call on each other--I learned an immense amount from my peers as well as Professor Sorkin.

Strengths: Prof. Sorkin is very good and very smart; the readings were interesting

Weaknesses: the readings were so high in volume that they were impossible to finish (at least for me!) Also Hegel and Nietzsche were incredibly hard.
One way it can be improved is to have a meeting as a class after the papers have been graded to talk about general problems as well as specific feedback with more time.
No weaknesses - DS is a great curriculum, though, and you just wish there was more time to read the texts.

I enjoyed this course immensely because of the complexity of the thinkers we studied, the engagement of the class, and the satisfying denouement that the intellectual trajectory of the texts gave to the entire year of Directed Studies. I don't have any ideas about major weaknesses, except perhaps that it would have been nice to do in person!
I think the course was really great and I cant think of any necessary improvements.

Strengths:  class discussions were always incredibly informative and productive
Weaknesses: some more feedback on papers perhaps as it was always very short and i wasn't always sure how to improve
I think Directed Studies is a fabulous program and Spring semester Historical & Political Thought course is undeniably a highlight. I struggle to think of any way the course could be improved.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think we made the most of the circumstances.
I'm not sure the discussion starters worked as well over Zoom as it might have in person, but other than that the course worked well over Zoom.

The virtual discussions were still very good and interesting! I don't think there was much that could be improved in the virtual format... I'm just happy that next year's DSers will get to experience this seminar in person.
zoom office hours have been extremely helpful to discuss ideas with the professor in a timely manner

Perhaps the course could have included some online reading responses or discussion boards, but the engagement of our section made this unnecessary in my opinion. Every aspect of the course functioned much the same as an in-person course would have.
I think DS did a good job considering the situation. I dont think there was really anything they could have done better.

Having a class discussant and having students call on each other (popcorn style almost) was very helpful in keeping the discussion moving and avoiding Zoom lulls where people weren't sure whose turn it was to talk.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes
I would recommend this course. One really learns how to put different thinkers in conversation with each other.

Definitely.  For me, I prefer the Philosophy and Literature tracks over H&P, but I still think H&P was really valuable, especially with the texts at the end of the semester.  In general, I think DS is an amazing program and I would definitely recommend it for students who are interested in the humanities and writing, even though it does have a limited Western focus.

I would. After reading the works on the syllabus, I feel that my understanding of modern politics has a theoretical basis point and that I understand many of the major conflicts in current theoretical debates. I loved reading and discussing almost every work, and I find the work of close-reading fun and fulfilling. Professor Sorkin was an incredibly thoughtful instructor, gave great feedback on papers, and was always willing to take question about my writing.
Yes I would! I love DS and DS has been so meaningful to me. The only warning I would give is that there is a ton of reading, which can be overwhelming if you're a slow reader like I am.

Yes, this is a wonderful course to develop a foundation for reading and writing. The texts that we read and discuss penetrate through modern contexts and will be a huge asset in future academic development.
Yes, and especially Prof. Sorkin. Hes so great at teaching and so willing to help and walk you through your papers & encourage you during the seminars.

I would very much recommend this course, and the Directed Studies curriculum as a whole, to any students who are deeply interested in the history of ideas and the irreducibility of great thinkers. More than a series of historical or political facts, this course taught me the joy that can be gleaned from putting the entire canon of Western intellectual in conversation with itself, and the creative potential that this process contains.

As with all DS classes, yes I would totally recommend it to someone who I think could handle it. I think taking DS is something that really requires you to be interested in what youre learning and excited to do all that work  but if you are, its totally an awesome experience.

Yes. I learned a lot about modern historical and political thought and Professor Sorkin was really good at helping us break down complex texts and stepping in to explain them when we got lost in our student discussions.

If a student is interested in history or politics, this course will provide them an excellent survey of the past 700 years of political thought that is valuable and enjoyable. If someone is even considering taking DS or wondering whether they should take the second semester, I would strongly urge them to do so. If a student has never even hear of DS, I would strongly urge them to research it and consider enrolling.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also prerecorded lectures.
Virtual seminar and recorded lectures
Once a week recorded lecture, twice a week virtual seminar
recorded lecture and virtual seminar
virtual lecture + virtual seminar
Recorded lecture and zoom seminar
virtual seminar on Zoom
both virtual seminars and recorded lectures
